date.event: Pranksters in England begin popularizing the practice of April Fool's jokes.
President RIchard Nixon bans radio and television advertisements for tobacco products.
Pope John Paul II, history's most well-traveled pope, dies in Rome.
Hans Christian Andersen, writer of The Little Mermaid and The Ugly Duckling, is born in Denmark.
The Pony Express debuts, setting a new standard for speedy mail delivery.
Woody Allen's movie Annie Hall beats George Lucas' Star Wars for the Best Picture Oscar.
Dr. Martin Luther King,Jr. is assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.
Wayne Gretzky finishes the NHL season with 212 points, becoming the first and only player to score more than 200 in one season.
Pocahontas of the Powhatan Indian confederacy marries English colonist John Rolfe.
Kurt Cobain of the band Nirvana commits suicide in Seattle at age 27.
The first modern Olympics, modeled after the ancient Grecian games, is held in Athens.
American Admiral Robert Peary becomes the first person to reach what he calculates to be the North Pole, although he is now thought to have been a few miles away.
Civil war and genocide erupts between the Hutu and Tutsi tribes of Rwanda.
The great Japanese battleship Yamato is sunk during the battle of Okinawa.
Hank Aaron hits his 715th home run, breaking Babe Ruth's record.
Congress establishes the Works Progress Association to employ people displaced by the Great Depression.
General Robert E. Lee surrenders, effectively ending the American Civil War.
The NASA's first astronauts, all military test pilots, are introduced proir to NASA's first missions in 1961.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) is founded.
Paul McCartney announces the breakup of the Beatles.
Emperor Napoleon of France gives up his throne and is exiled to the Mediterranean isle of Elba.
The Apollo 13 lunar lander is successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida.
The Civil War begins with a Confederate attack on Fort Sumter.
President Franklin Delano Roosevelt dies after 12 years in office.
Tiger Woods wins his first major golf tournament at age 21.
Sidney Poitier becomes the first African American to win the Best Actor Oscar for his role in Lilies of the Field.
President Abraham Lincoln is shot by John Wilkes Booth at Ford's Theater in Washington.
Webster's American Dictionary of the English Language is first published.
Jackie Robinson becomes the first African American player of major league baseball.
The RMS Titanic sinks in the North Atlantic ocean after striking an iceberg.
Vladimir Lenin returns to Russia from exile to lead the Russian Revolution.
Hollywood legend Charlie Chaplin is born in London, England.
After suffering serious equipment malfunctions on their way to the moon, the Apollo 13 lander and its crew returns successfully to Earth.
American statesman, printer inventor and diplomat Bejamin Frianklin dies at age 84.
An earthquake estimated at over 8.0 on the Richter scale hits San Francisco, causing widespread fires and destruction.
American movie star Grace Kelly marries Prince Rainier of Monaco.
The first Boston Marathon is won by John McDermott of New York. Fifteen runners started the race, but only 10 finished.
The American Revolutionary War begins with the Battle of Lexington in Massachusetts.
Danica Patrick wins the Indy Japan 300, becoming the first female driver to win an IndyCar race.
Two teenage gunment kill 13 people at Columbine High School in Colorado.
According to tradition, Rome was founded by twin brothers Romulus and Remus.
The feared German dogfighter known as the Red Baron is killed in action in France during the first World War.
The first Earth Day is celebrated in the United States.
Adolf Hitler admits to his confederates that Germany has lost the second World War.
Poet and playwright William Shakespeare is likely born in the town of Stratford-on-Avon, England; he died on the same day in 1616.
Hank Aaron hits the first home run of his Major League baseball career.
On Easter Monday, Irish militants begin a violent rebellion against British rule.
The Library of Congress is established and eventually becomes the de facto national library of the United States.
Construction begins on the Suez Canal, to connect the Red Sea and Mediterranean.
Daniel Defoe's novel Robinson Crusoe is first published.
The first polio vaccine trials begin, preventing the disease in over 1.8 million children.
The world's worst nuclear power plant accident occurs at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Soviet Union.
British Parliament passes the Tea Act, granting a monopoly to the East India Company and angering American colonists.
South Africa holds its first multiracial elections, choosing Nelson Mandela as its new leader.
Benito Mussolini, the exiled former dictator of Italy, is executed.
Ferruccio Lamborghini, the founder of the company that bears his name and is known for stylish, high-performance cars, is born in Italy.
The National World War II Memorial opens in Washington, D.C., to thousands of visitors.
17-year-old French peasant Joan of Arc leads a French force in relieving the city of Orleans to aid French crown prince Charles in expelling British troops.
The first American presidential inauguration is held, officially making George Washington the first President of the United States.
South Vietnam surrenders, effectively ending the Vietnam War and uniting the country.
